title: What is the role of a pianist? - Quora

response.answer_text: Some people say you should make the piece of music “your own” and “bring something out that no-one else has.” The implication is that this will make you a good musician and your performances interesting, compelling or otherwise deserving of a listen. If that’s true, I’m a genius, as you can tell by each of my interpretations of this Brahms Intermezzo, op. 16, no. 6, in E, for piano: Let’s play it on a completely ruined piano http://www.paulhenrysmith.com/wp-content/uploads/intermezzo-op.-116-no.-6-RUINEDPIANO.mp3 Let’s “interpret” the timing http://www.paulhenrysmith.com/wp-content/uploads/intermezzo-op.-116-no.-6-TIMING.mp3 I like the parts that aren’t the melody. They’re more “interesting” than just hearing the melody as prominent all the time. I mean, how boring! http://www.paulhenrysmith.com/wp-content/uploads/intermezzo-op.-116-no.-6-WRONG-MELODY.mp3 Here’s some other non-melodic bits forced to become the “main part.” http://www.paulhenrysmith.com/wp-content/uploads/intermezzo-op.-116-no.-6-WRONG-MELODY-2.mp3 I think it’s more interesting to hear it faster. After all, we live in an age when you can travel over 500 mph. Brahms didn’t. http://www.paulhenrysmith.com/wp-content/uploads/intermezzo-op.-116-no.-6-TOO-FAST.mp3 Or, let’s try going slow enough to ponder and weigh each moment. http://www.paulhenrysmith.com/wp-content/uploads/intermezzo-op.-116-no.-6-TOO-SLOW.mp3 Come to think of it, why should I play the measures in the order in which they are printed? http://www.paulhenrysmith.com/wp-content/uploads/intermezzo-op.-116-no.-6-RANDOM-ORDER.mp3 Or, how about in this order? http://www.paulhenrysmith.com/wp-content/uploads/intermezzo-op.-116-no.-6-WRONG-ORDER.mp3 I like surprises! http://www.paulhenrysmith.com/wp-content/uploads/intermezzo-op.-116-no.-6-RANDOM-ACCENTS.mp3 Sometimes it’s just beautiful pianism to linger. Just … linger!! http://www.paulhenrysmith.com/wp-content/uploads/intermezzo-op.-116-no.-6-RANDOM-RUBATO.mp3 Or, push! PUSH! http://www.paulhenrysmith.com/wp-content/uploads/intermezzo-op.-116-no.-6-XTREME-RUBATO.mp3 Now let’s bring out the bass. http://www.paulhenrysmith.com/wp-content/uploads/intermezzo-op.-116-no.-6-SUBBASS.mp3 Octave equivalency means I can do this. http://www.paulhenrysmith.com/wp-content/uploads/intermezzo-op.-116-no.-6-WRONG-OCTAVE.mp3 Maybe add some popular music idiomatic element? http://www.paulhenrysmith.com/wp-content/uploads/intermezzo-op.-116-no.-6-FAST-DRUMS.mp3 While we’re at it, it don’t mean a thing if it ain’t got … http://www.paulhenrysmith.com/wp-content/uploads/intermezzo-op.-116-no.-6-SWING-DRUMS.mp3 Hell, I don’t know why we need to limit ourselves to piano. If Brahms had ever seen a drum set, I bet he would approve of this. http://www.paulhenrysmith.com/wp-content/uploads/intermezzo-op.-116-no.-6-DRUMSET.mp3 Or, you could just try to put the sounds together in such a way that they align with the given elements written down by Brahms. http://www.paulhenrysmith.com/wp-content/uploads/brahms-intermezzo-op116-no6-FULL.mp3

I think it depends on what type of music we are talking about. For classical piano, the general expectation is that the pianist will keep to the score as written-the role of the pianist here would be to interpret the music. To do this, generally the pianist will use the notations on the score in addition to whatever knowledge he or she would have regarding the composer’s mood as well as the circumstances when the piece was written. Sometimes that information is known, sometimes not. For example, Chopin’s “Revolutionary Etude” was composed after Chopin found out that Poland had been conquered. This was a man who was fiercely proud of his country, and had to leave in order to avoid imprisonment and to find his way in the music world. He was sad and angry when he wrote this piece, and it is this mood that the pianist needs to convey. Generally with classical music, the more you know about the composer, his style, and the circumstances around the music, the better the interpretation can be, but sometimes, you don’t have the information regarding the circumstances-so you use the score to help figure out how it should be performed as well as previous performances of the piece. There are accepted interpretations-for example a performance of the first movement of the “Moonlight Sonata” is generally not played loudly, and such a performance isn’t considered to be a legitimate interpretation of the piece. For jazz or pop or any other form of music, sticking to exactly what is written is not the norm-improvising is encouraged and routinely done, so the role of the pianist here would literally be to create something from the bare bones guidance of whatever score they would be given.
